about.p11: vodle helps a group make fair and good decisions. It finds the maximum partial consensus among any set of options. Truly democratic, it gives everyone the same effective influence.
about.p12: For each option, it shows you the current approval as a light bar on the right, and allows you to adjust your ratings in real-time using sliders. When your slider touches the approval bar, it turns green to indicate that you approve that option as well. This way, the group tends to converge to a full or partial consensus that is as broad as possible.
about.p13: When the poll closes, the winning option is determined by a fair but simple algorithm that gives every voter the same influence, not just those voters who happen to be in a majority.
about.p14: In choice polls (where your group is selecting a single option), the decision is made as follows. If one option is approved by all, this full consensus option wins. Otherwise vodle most likely declares the option with the broadest approval the winner. But to achieve fairness, vodle must sometimes also use a certain amount of chance, similar to a greencard lottery.
about.p15: The exact procedure that vodle uses for determining the winning option is this: After the poll has closed, options are sorted by descending approval, and one voter is picked by lot. The top-most option for which that voter's slider is green wins.
about.p16: This way, the most-approved option will have the vastly largest probability of winning. Other options' winning probabilities are at most as large as their approval scores (in percent of all voters who do not abstain).
about.p17: In allocation polls (where your group is dividing some budget or resource into shares for several targets or recipients), the procedure is similar: If one target is approved by all, you have full consensus, so this target will get the full budget. Otherwise vodle allocates the largest share of the budget to the target with the broadest approval, and smaller shares to the other targets.
about.p18: Exact procedure: Targets are sorted by descending approval. Then each target's share is proportional to the number of voters who have approved this target but no higher-up target.
about.p21: vodle's algorithm (called “maximum partial consensus”) was developed and optimizied for fairness by the mathematician Jobst Heitzig in collaboration with Forest W. Simmons. It is inspired by the “threshold model” of famous sociologist Mark Granovetter. This app is open-source, code hosted on github. Main developer: Jobst Heitzig. Contributors: Marius Amrhein, Adrian Lison.
about.p31: As we are committed to keep vodle free for everyone, we still need further help. If you are a nerd, creative, influencer, scientist, philanthropist, activist, politician, friendly alien... who believes in the future of fair & efficient consensus making and want to contribute in whatever small way, we have some ideas how you might support us!

delegation-request.intro: You can ask some other voter to act as your delegate. The delegate will then control your ratings instead of you. In other words, their ratings will be used as your ratings, too. The delegate can also delegate their and your ratings further to some third voter, and so on. You can revoke the delegation at any time, and can also always choose to still rate some of the options yourself.

help.p11c: or click on a poll link that was sent to you.
help.p12a: Rate the options (or targets) by using the sliders. Vodle interprets your rating of an option as your “willingness to approve” that option.
help.p12b: Give your favourite option a rating of 100 (drag the slider completely to the right). This way you approve that option for sure.
help.p12c: Give every option that you find better than average a rating larger than zero (slider gets blue or green). This means you are willing to approve this option under certain conditions.
help.p12d: Leave options that you find worse than average at zero (slider is a red dot). This means you won't approve these options no matter what.
help.p13a: As long as the poll is running, adjust your “willingness to approve” ratings to the situation:
help.p13b: The light bars to the right show what options currently get much approval.
help.p13c: If you think an option is an acceptable compromise or is even a potential consensus, then increase your “willingness to approve” rating until the slider enters the bar and gets green. (If it already overlaps the bar quite much, you can also move it somewhat to the left so that it overlaps only little.)
help.p14: Options are listed by descending approval, the most approved option is always on top.
help.p15a: The pie charts to the left determine the result of the poll when it closes:
help.p15b1: In a poll for selecting a
help.p15b2: single option, the pie pieces show how probable it is that each option wins.
help.p15c2: shares of a budget, the pie pieces show the shares that will be allocated to each possible target.
help.p21: By rating all options, you indicate your “willingness to approve” each option. All voters' ratings then determine which options (or targets) you actually approve. At any moment in time while the poll runs, every voter approves some number of options – zero, one, or more than one. When the poll closes, the approval is used to determine the winner or budget shares in a way explained further down.
help.p22: But first: How does your willingness to approve determine whether you actually approve an opton or not? If you rate an option at 100, it means you definitely approve that option, and if you rate it at zero, you definitely don't approve that option.
help.p23:
But what if your rating of some option is somewhere between 0 and 100? The main thing to understand is that whether or not you approve the option then also depends on the other voters' willingness to approve that option! The main idea is that your “willingness to approve” rating is a kind of promise. By giving an option a rating larger than zero, you promise to approve that option if enough other voters do so as well. How many are “enough”? That depends on how far to the right you move your rating slider. If your rating is at, say, 83, that means you promise to approve the option if less than 83% of the voters disapprove the option – or, equivalently: if more than 17% of the voters do approve the option. In other words, the larger your rating, the fewer voters you require to also approve the option before you are willing to approve it as well.
In the app, you can see very easily whether you currently approve an option, because we show you the percentage of current approvers as a light bar coming in from the right of the screen. If your slider, coming in from the left, meets that bar, then the percentage of voters not approving that option is lower than your rating, so your condition for approval is met and you are counted as approving the option. Your slider then turns from blue to green to indicate that you approve the option.
help.p24: Now that we have understood how approval is calculated, we can turn to the question of how the winning probabilities (budget shares) are found and how the actual winner is determined if the poll is about picking a single option. If exactly one option has 100% approval, it will win for sure (or get all of the budget). If several options each have 100% approval, the one among them that has the largest total rating will win for sure (or get all of the budget). If no option has 100% approval, vodle distributes the winning probability or budget among two or more options. In that case, the option with the largest approval will win most likely or get the largest share. But other options that have at least some approval may then win as well with some smaller probability, or also get some smaller share of the budget. For polls selecting a single option this means that then there is a certain chance element involved to determine the actual winner. This is because we must make sure that no group of voters can simply be ignored by the other voters as it is the case with majority rule. This way, vodle gives every voter the exact same influence and gives every faction an influence that matches its size.
help.p25: If the poll is about selecting one option, the exact procedure to find the winner when no option has 100% approval is very simple. One voter is determined by lot, everyone having the same chance of being that voter. Among the options that this voter approves, the one with the largest overall approval is the winner. The pie piece to the left of each option shows the resulting probability that this option wins.
help.p26: If the poll is about allocating a budget, the size of each option's shares is calculated the same way: the share is proportional to the number of voters that (i) approve this option but (ii) do not approve any other option that has a larger overall approval.
help.p27: So now we know how the winner or the shares are found. But how should you now set your “willingness to approve” ratings? The following rule of thumb usually works quite well to find a good consensus: Give your favourite a rating of 100. Give all options which are better than average some rating larger than zero, scaling your ratings according to relative preference. Finally, give all options which are worse than average a rating of zero.

joinpoll.fetching: Just a moment please, I'm fetching this poll's data...
joinpoll.initializing: Just a moment please, I'm initializing the poll...
joinpoll.p1-winner: This poll is about deciding between a number of options until {{due}}. In the end, exactly one option will win.
joinpoll.p1-share: This poll is about dividing some resource or budget between a number of targets until {{due}}.
joinpoll.p2: Some options have already been suggested. Any participant in the poll can suggest further options at any time, until the poll closes.
joinpoll.p3: You can express your opinion about the suggested options by rating them. You can give each option a rating between 0 (don't approve) and 100 (approve for sure).
joinpoll.p4: If you are unsure about one or more options, you can also delegate those ratings to someone you trust. In that case, that person's ratings of these options counts for you as well. If you don't have the time to think about the options at all, you can also delegate all of your ratings to someone else.
joinpoll.p5: You can change your ratings or delegations at any time until the poll closes. In fact, it often makes sense to monitor the poll's development over time, adjust your ratings to what you see, rate additional options that might get suggested, or add options yourself. That way, you can together find a good compromise or reach consensus.
joinpoll.p6: If you want to know how the ratings are used by vodle to determine the results, see {{link_start}}here{{link_end}}.
